metadata.case_name: Thakur Bahadur Singh v. State of Rajasthan

facts.text: Thakur Nathu Singh, the Jagirdar of Ras (a Scheduled Jagir under the Marwar Act) died in July 1946 leaving the petitioner, Thakur Bahadur Singh as his next heir.
Scheduled Jagirs under the Marwar Act are impartible and succession governed by rule of primogeniture under s.182.
Succession to Scheduled Jagir not automatic; requires recognition by Government and renewal of grant (ss.183-185 Marwar Act).
On death of holder, Scheduled Jagir resumed by Government until renewal; claimant (direct lineal descendant) permitted possession pending orders.
Title of petitioner to succeed recognized and renewal granted by Government order dated March 18, 1952.
Rajasthan Land Reforms and Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1952 received President's assent on February 13, 1952, came into force on publication in Gazette on February 16, 1952.
Under s.190 Marwar Act, succeeding heir must execute Kabuliyat for payment of Hukamnama and other fees within one month of communication of orders; amount payable by petitioner: Rs. 30,000.
Respondent-State demanded Rs. 30,000 hukamnama from petitioner.
Petitioner resists demand relying on s.4(a) Rajasthan Act, claiming hukamnama is 'tribute' extinguished from commencement of Act.
Rajasthan High Court in Thakur Narpat Singh v. State of Rajasthan (ILR 1955 Raj 534) held on identical facts that hukamnama under s.190 Marwar Act not within s.4(a) Rajasthan Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the liability to pay hukamnama or other fees under s.190 of the Marwar Land Revenue Act, 1949 is a 'tribute' within the meaning of s.2(r) and extinguished by s.4(a) of the Rajasthan Land Reforms and Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1952.
Whether s.4 of Rajasthan Act is retrospective, relating back to date succession opened (July 1946).

petitioner_arguments.text: Hukamnama is 'tribute' as per inclusive definition in s.2(r) Rajasthan Act, which includes dictionary meanings (tax, impost, duty, rental paid by vassal to sovereign) beyond enumerated recurring dues like rekh, rakam etc.; not limited to recurring payments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(r), s.4(a) Rajasthan Act; Webster's and Oxford Dictionary definitions of 'tribute'

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in confining 'tribute' to recurring charges of similar nature, ignoring inclusive nature of definition.

respondent_arguments.text: s.4 Rajasthan Act not retrospective; recognition/renewal relates back to July 1946 when succession opened, so obligation accrued before Act.

Hukamnama not 'tribute'; it is ad hoc payment for recognition of succession/renewal, not recurring annual payment like rekh, rakam, chatund, chakri enumerated in s.2(r); paid by claimant, not Jagirdar as such; reflects sovereign pleasure/ownership (ss.169-170 Marwar Act).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(r), s.4(a) Rajasthan Act; ss.169,170,182-185,190 Marwar Act

court_reasoning.text: Declined to entertain respondent's retrospectivity argument as not raised in answer to petition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Point not raised in State's answer; not permitted.

court_reasoning.text: s.2(r) inclusive definition covers enumerated recurring annual payments (rekh etc.) and 'other charges of a similar nature'; hukamnama is ad hoc, not recurring/annual.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court reasoning followed but on different line: context of entire Act shows 'tribute' means recurring payments attributable to specific years.

court_reasoning.text: Word 'tribute' used in s.8 (land revenue based on prior tribute for specific years), Sch II r.4 (net income deducts tribute for basic year), Sch III (rehabilitation grant comparisons based on tribute-paying status) â€“ all indicate recurring annual payments, not ad hoc like hukamnama.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner's broad dictionary construction would disadvantage Jagirdars, unintended by framers.

court_reasoning.text: 'Tribute' used as compendious term for local imposts in integrated Rajasthan States; not general dictionary meaning.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act's provisions limit to recurring dues.

holdings.text: Hukamnama and fees under s.190 Marwar Act not 'tribute' within s.4(a) Rajasthan Act; liability not extinguished.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Narpat Singh v. State of Rajasthan
precedents_cited.relevance: Identical facts; held hukamnama under s.190 Marwar Act not tribute under s.4(a) Rajasthan Act (same conclusion by SC, different reasoning)

statutes_cited.name: Rajasthan Land Reforms and Resumption of Jagirs Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: 'Tribute' defined inclusively; extinguished by s.4(a) but limited to recurring payments; used in computing land revenue, net income for compensation, rehabilitation grants

statutes_cited.name: Marwar Land Revenue Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs Scheduled Jagirs: succession, renewal, hukamnama on recognition; ownership vests in ruler

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for petition enforcing fundamental rights

outcome.summary: The petition under Art.32 challenging demand for hukamnama as extinguished by Rajasthan Act fails; on construction of 'tribute', petitioner has no legal grievance; petition dismissed.

key_quotes.text: Notwithstanding therefore that the definition in s. 2(r) of the Rajasthan Act is inclusive it appears to us from an examination of the meaning of the word as used in the operative provisions of the Act, that it could refer only to recurring payments which could be said to be attributable to particular years and not to the type of ad hoc payments of which hukamnamas and patta-fees are examples.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding distinguishing 'tribute' as recurring, not ad hoc

key_quotes.text: We have thus reached the same conclusion as the learned Judges of the Rajasthan High Court, though on a different line of reasoning.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms High Court but provides new reasoning based on Act's context
